Test your knowledge of the important cell types used in forensic science. Select the best answer for each question and click "Check Answer" to see if you got it right.

<div class="lesson-card">
  <h3>What type of cells in saliva are used in forensic investigations, and why are they useful?</h3>
<div class="question-options">
  <label><input type="radio" name="q1" value="1"> Epithelial cells, because they contain DNA that can be used to identify individuals</label>
  <label><input type="radio" name="q1" value="2"> Red blood cells, because they carry oxygen</label>
  <label><input type="radio" name="q1" value="3"> White blood cells, because they fight infections</label>
  <label><input type="radio" name="q1" value="4"> Nerve cells, because they transmit signals</label>
</div>
  <button class="btn check-btn" onclick="checkAnswer(1)">Check Answer</button>
  <div id="result-1" class="result-message"></div>
</div>

<div class="lesson-card">
  <h3>Which forensic evidence sources commonly contain epithelial cells that can be analyzed for DNA?</h3>
<div class="question-options">
  <label><input type="radio" name="q2" value="1"> Cups, cigarettes, and bite marks</label>
  <label><input type="radio" name="q2" value="2"> Only blood samples</label>
  <label><input type="radio" name="q2" value="3"> Hair follicles exclusively</label>
</div>
  <button class="btn check-btn" onclick="checkAnswer(2)">Check Answer</button>
  <div id="result-2" class="result-message"></div>
</div>

<div class="lesson-card">
  <h3>What is the primary purpose of studying different epithelial cell types in forensic science?</h3>
<div class="question-options">
  <label><input type="radio" name="q3" value="1"> To understand and compare physical attributes of cells from different body sources</label>
  <label><input type="radio" name="q3" value="2"> To determine the age of evidence</label>
  <label><input type="radio" name="q3" value="3"> To identify the time of death</label>
  <label><input type="radio" name="q3" value="4"> To determine weapon types used</label>
</div>
  <button class="btn check-btn" onclick="checkAnswer(3)">Check Answer</button>
  <div id="result-3" class="result-message"></div>
</div>

<div class="lesson-card">
  <h3>Why is saliva evidence especially useful in forensic investigations?</h3>
<div class="question-options">
  <label><input type="radio" name="q4" value="1"> It never degrades over time</label>
  <label><input type="radio" name="q4" value="2"> It can link suspects to crimes or confirm identities</label>
  <label><input type="radio" name="q4" value="3"> It only comes from criminals</label>
</div>
  <button class="btn check-btn" onclick="checkAnswer(4)">Check Answer</button>
  <div id="result-4" class="result-message"></div>
</div>

<script>
function checkAnswer(questionNum) {
const selected = document.querySelector(`input[name="q${questionNum}"]:checked`);
const resultDiv = document.getElementById(`result-${questionNum}`);

if (!selected) {
resultDiv.innerHTML = '<p style="color: orange;">Please select an answer!</p>';
return;
}

// Correct answers: Q1=1, Q2=1, Q3=1, Q4=2
const correctAnswers = {1: '1', 2: '1', 3: '1', 4: '2'};
const correctAnswer = correctAnswers[questionNum];

if (selected.value === correctAnswer) {
resultDiv.innerHTML = '<p style="color: green;">✓ Correct!</p>';
} else {
const correctText = {
1: 'Epithelial cells, because they contain DNA that can be used to identify individuals',
2: 'Cups, cigarettes, and bite marks',
3: 'To understand and compare physical attributes of cells from different body sources',
4: 'It can link suspects to crimes or confirm identities'
};
resultDiv.innerHTML = `<p style="color: red;">✗ Incorrect. The correct answer is: ${correctText[questionNum]}.</p>`;
}
}
</script>
